metadata.title: Domain-Invariant Projection Learning for Zero-Shot Recognition
metadata.author: An Zhao, Mingyu Ding, Jiechao Guan, Zhiwu Lu, Tao Xiang, Ji-Rong Wen
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) aims to recognize unseen object classes without any training samples, which can be regarded as a form of transfer learning from seen classes to unseen ones. This is made possible by learning a projection between a feature space and a semantic space (e.g. attribute space). Key to ZSL is thus to learn a projection function that is robust against the often large domain gap between the seen and unseen classes. In this paper, we propose a novel ZSL model termed domain-invariant projection learning (DIPL). Our model has two novel components: (1) A domain-invariant feature self-reconstruction task is introduced to the seen/unseen class data, resulting in a simple linear formulation that casts ZSL into a min-min optimization problem. Solving the problem is non-trivial, and a novel iterative algorithm is formulated as the solver, with rigorous theoretic algorithm analysis provided. (2) To further align the two domains via the learned projection, shared semantic structure among seen and unseen classes is explored via forming superclasses in the semantic space. Extensive experiments show that our model outperforms the state-of-the-art alternatives by significant margins.

highlights: The recent focus on object recognition has been on large-scale recognition problems such as the ImageNet ILSVRC challenge [47]
We propose a novel zero-shot learning model termed domain-invariant projection learning (DIPL)

Seen/unseen classes within a superclass seen: unicycle; unseen: hard hat seen: freight car; unseen: ferris wheel seen: hair slide; unseen: nail polish seen: ox; seen: bison unseen: coffee bean; unseen: Arabian coffee; unseen: cacao superclasses that consist of semantically-related seen and unseen classes, which means that the unseen class samples can become ‘seen’ in zero-shot learning with superclasses and easier to recognize
We have proposed a domain-invariant projection learning (DIPL) model for zero-shot recognition
Extensive experiments on five benchmark datasets show that our domain-invariant projection learning model yields state-of-the-art results under all three zero-shot learning settings

It is worth pointing out that the proposed optimization algorithm is by no means restricted to the zero-shot learning problem – many other vision problems need to deal with a min-min problem and our gradient-based formulation can be induced
key_statements: The recent focus on object recognition has been on large-scale recognition problems such as the ImageNet ILSVRC challenge [47]
(2) To further align the two domains via the learned projection, shared semantic structure among seen and unseen classes is explored via forming superclasses in the semantic space
The recent focus on object recognition has been on large-scale recognition problems such as the ImageNet ILSVRC challenge [47]
All existing zero-shot learning models assume that each class name is embedded in a semantic space, such as attribute space [22, 25] or word vector space [14, 54]
We propose a novel zero-shot learning model termed domain-invariant projection learning (DIPL)

Transductive zero-shot learning is proposed to tackle the projection domain shift [16, 23, 45] caused by the domain gap, through learning with not only the training set of labelled seen class data but the test set of unlabelled unseen class data

Our domain-invariant projection learning model integrates both forward and reverse projections for zero-shot learning, so that a feature vector representing the visual appearance of an object will be projected into a semantic space and back to reconstruct itself

Assuming that the forward and reverse projections have the same importance for zero-shot learning, our domain-invariant projection learning model solves the following optimization problem: Ns min W i=1
The comparative results under the standard zero-shot learning setting are shown in Table 2

To provide more convergence analysis for Algorithm 1, we define three baseline projection matrices based on the DIPL0 model: 1) Wall – learned by DIPL0 using the whole dataset; 2) Wtr – learned by DIPL0 only using the training set; 3) Wte – learned by DIPL0 only using the test set

Seen/unseen classes within a superclass seen: unicycle; unseen: hard hat seen: freight car; unseen: ferris wheel seen: hair slide; unseen: nail polish seen: ox; seen: bison unseen: coffee bean; unseen: Arabian coffee; unseen: cacao superclasses that consist of semantically-related seen and unseen classes, which means that the unseen class samples can become ‘seen’ in zero-shot learning with superclasses and easier to recognize
Only evaluated in the area of zero-shot learning, our bidirectional model can be applied to other problem settings where a mapping between a feature and a semantic space is required
We have proposed a domain-invariant projection learning (DIPL) model for zero-shot recognition
A novel iterative algorithm has been developed for model optimization, followed by rigorous theoretic algorithm analysis
Extensive experiments on five benchmark datasets show that our domain-invariant projection learning model yields state-of-the-art results under all three zero-shot learning settings

It is worth pointing out that the proposed optimization algorithm is by no means restricted to the zero-shot learning problem – many other vision problems need to deal with a min-min problem and our gradient-based formulation can be induced
summary: The recent focus on object recognition has been on large-scale recognition problems such as the ImageNet ILSVRC challenge [47].
Without any labels, the unseen class data has limited effect in overcoming the domain gap using existing transductive ZSL models.
We propose a novel ZSL model termed domain-invariant projection learning (DIPL).
By imposing such forward and reverse projection learning on the seen/useen class data, our DIPL model takes a simple linear formulation that casts ZSL into a min-min optimization problem.

Our contributions are: (1) A novel transductive ZSL model is proposed which aligns the seen and unsee class domains using domain-invariant feature self-reconstruction and superclasses shared across domain alignment.

Transductive ZSL is proposed to tackle the projection domain shift [16, 23, 45] caused by the domain gap, through learning with not only the training set of labelled seen class data but the test set of unlabelled unseen class data.

Our DIPL model integrates both forward and reverse projections for ZSL, so that a feature vector representing the visual appearance of an object will be projected into a semantic space and back to reconstruct itself.
Assuming that the forward and reverse projections have the same importance for ZSL, our DIPL model solves the following optimization problem: Ns min W i=1
In our ZSL problem, this improved generalization ability makes the learned regression model more applicable to the unseen class domain.

Our DIPL model is employed for ZSL with superclasses as follows: 1) Group all unseen and seen class prototypes [Ys, Yu] into r clusters by k-means clustering and represent the superclass prototypes with the cluster centers

It can be seen that: (1) Our model performs the best on all five datasets, validating that the combination of domain-invariant feature self-reconstruction and superclasses shared across domain alignment is effective for learning domain-invariant projection.

To provide more convergence analysis for Algorithm 1, we define three baseline projection matrices based on the DIPL0 model: 1) Wall – learned by DIPL0 using the whole dataset; 2) Wtr – learned by DIPL0 only using the training set; 3) Wte – learned by DIPL0 only using the test set.
Only evaluated in the area of ZSL, our bidirectional model can be applied to other problem settings where a mapping between a feature and a semantic space is required.
Extensive experiments on five benchmark datasets show that our DIPL model yields state-of-the-art results under all three ZSL settings.
Our current efforts include its generalization to solve a wider range of vision problems
headline: We propose a novel zero-shot learning model termed domain-invariant projection learning
